awd_titl_txt: Physical regulation of cellular respiration by membrane lipid composition
awd_abstract_narration:
The chemical energy that cells use for growth is generated using respiration, a universal set of reactions that occur partly within lipid membranes. Lipid composition is used by cells to modulate the properties of their membranes, which could act as important physical structures for reactions that occur during respiration. In this project, novel synthetic biology approaches will be used to investigate biophysical roles for lipid chemistry and membrane structure in respiratory activity. This research will provide mechanistic insight into respiratory function and cell physiology that is applicable to a wide variety of organisms and is relevant to understanding the interplay of diet and disease in human health. In addition to the research activities, this grant will support education and outreach efforts that focus on scientific training for underprivileged high school and undergraduate students. These efforts will teach students fundamental concepts in metabolism and provide hands-on experience with emerging biotechnology research projects in order to support their future careers in science and technology.

Efforts to engineer fatty acid composition in bacteria have led to the observation that fluidizing lipid components, such as unsaturated lipids, act as a general regulator of respiratory metabolism. The project will test the hypothesis that respiratory flux by is controlled by the lipid-mediated diffusion rates of electron transport chain components. This will be done with a combination of biophysical measurements, physiological experiments, and physical modeling of bacterial respiratory chains. Lipid composition varies tremendously among prokaryotes and this could partly be understood through differences in their metabolic requirements. The project will therefore use synthetic biology approaches to assess the metabolic effects of isoprenoid-based membrane components that modulate membrane structure in a heterologous bacterial host. Lipid composition is also tightly regulated in mitochondrial membranes, which carry out respiration in all eukaryotic cells. The project will use engineered yeast strains to systematically investigate the role of fatty acid composition in mitochondrial structure and respiratory activity. These systems will serve as models for understanding how lipid composition can affect metabolic functions and may be broadly applicable to many important processes.

por.por_cntn:
Physical regulation of cellular respiration by membrane lipid composition

MCB-1715681

PI: Jay D. Keasling (UC Berkeley); Co-PI: Itay Budin (UC San Diego)

8/1/2017-7/31/2021


Project Outcome Report

 

This project sought to apply systems and synthetic biology approaches to understand the membrane-bound reactions of the electron transport chain (ETC), a fundamental metabolic process carried out by all cells. By engineering lipid biosynthesis, the team built a cellular chassis in Escherichia coli, a common model bacterium, in which a biophysical parameter of the inner membrane (its fluidity or viscosity) could be experimentally controlled. This system was used to characterize how respiration rates were controlled by membrane properties. These results then led to the development of a mathematical model of the bacterial ETC that was predictive of respiration rates in whole cells. The model was based on the diffusion of specific molecules (ubiquinones) that transport electrons across ETC. Thus, careful engineering of a lipid biosynthetic pathway led to mechanistic insights on cell metabolism. 

 

The project?s work on the ETC has been extended to analyzing the membranes of mitochondria, which carry out respiration in all eukaryotic cells. This has allowed the central implications of the work to be extended to metabolism across organisms, including humans. In other research activities, the project carried out similar engineering efforts in Zymomonas mobilis, a bacterium with industrial relevance for bioethanol production. In this case, the project discovered how an exotic group of lipids (hopanoids) contribute to its ability to carry out metabolism under solvent stress. Together, these activities have demonstrated the capability of using synthetic biology to investigate cell membranes in a range of experimental systems.

 

The broader impacts of the project included both its scientific contributions and outreach/education activities it sponsored. The research increased our understanding of how lipids, a poorly understood group of molecules that are directly tied to diet and health in humans, contribute to metabolic performance. Furthermore, it introduced a new biophysical for the function of cell respiration, which has potential relevance to cellular function widely. The reagents developed by the project, namely bacterial and yeast model organisms for controlling lipid composition, have been made available to other researchers studying membrane-associated processes. Finally, the project supported high school education activities as part of the JBEI (Joint Bioenergy Institute) iCLEM summer program, which seeks to expose students from underrepresented backgrounds to careers in scientific research.
